title: Episode 137 – Georgia Kelly, Founder, Praxis Peace Institute; on the Mondragon Cooperatives
subtitle: ABOUT THE MONDRAGON COOPERATIVES
description: The Mondragon Cooperatives were founded in the 1950s with five initial owner-members under the thoughtful guidance of Father Don Jose Arizmendiarrieta (aka “Arizmendi”), whose socially progressive and community-oriented leanings launched a corporate and governance structure that would help to propel thousands of families into prosperity. Rooted in the Basque region of Spain, where the Basque people have endured ethnic discrimination and violence (including under the fascist regime of dictator Franco), the Mondragon Cooperatives are founded on ten fundamental principles:
full_transcript:
[10.3s - 17.8s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,

[18.0s - 30.0s]: we're visiting with Georgia Kelly, the Executive Director of the Praxis Peace Institute. Hi,

[30.0s - 38.8s]: and I am so excited for this conversation in particular. It feels as if I've been anticipating this

[38.8s - 45.7s]: for 20, 25 years, which might become clear in the course of our conversation why. But essentially,

[46.1s - 55.2s]: the reason is, you're an expert on the Mondragon Cooperative System and amazing community and corporate

[55.8s - 62.4s]: structure over in the Basque region of Spain, which is going to form much of the topic of our

[62.4s - 72.3s]: conversation today. Right. So excited. I hate hesitate to use the word expert. I feel like I

[72.3s - 77.8s]: know a fair amount because I've been there many times and spent a lot of time there, but I hesitate

[77.8s - 82.7s]: to use that word. No problem whatsoever. I'll use it for you.

[84.4s - 90.6s]: Georgia Kelly is the founder and executive director of Praxis Peace Institute. She has produced and

[90.6s - 96.6s]: directed several multi-day conferences in Europe and the United States and continues to create

[96.6s - 103.1s]: educational programs for Praxis. In addition to leading seminars and tours abroad in places like

[103.1s - 110.3s]: Italy, Cuba, Croatia, and Spain, she developed a week-long seminar and tour at the Mondragon

[110.3s - 117.0s]: Cooperatives in Spain, which has become a signature program at Praxis. As a dedicated advocate for

[117.0s - 123.4s]: cooperatives, she compiled the Mondragon report and account of how the Praxis and Mondragon seminar

[123.4s - 129.9s]: has impacted the cooperative movement in the United States. Georgia is also an active citizen and

[129.9s - 136.1s]: has chaired several issue-based political organizations and educational forums. She served as a

[136.1s - 143.3s]: delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1992. That's Governor Jerry Brown in California.

[144.2s - 149.6s]: Georgia also holds a certificate in conflict resolution from Sonoma State University

[150.3s - 156.8s]: and teaches conflict resolution workshops and mediation. In 2013, she edited and co-authored

[156.8s - 164.5s]: uncivil liberties, deconstructing libertarianism, a critique of libertarian ideas and laissez-faire

[164.5s - 171.9s]: capitalism written from the perspective of three academics and three activists. Her previous career was

[171.9s - 178.5s]: as a musician, harpist, composer, and recording artist. And Georgia, it's such a pleasure to have you

[178.5s - 183.4s]: on the show. And I believe that what we're going to be talking about today, particularly the

[183.4s - 190.1s]: Mondragon cooperatives, provides such a tremendously important framework for many of us engaged in this

[190.1s - 195.9s]: regenerative stewardship sustainability movement. And I find in many of my conversations, especially

[195.9s - 200.9s]: here in the United States, that a handful of folks here and there are aware of the Mondragon

[200.9s - 205.7s]: cooperatives, but a whole lot of folks are already engaged in really important work, aren't yet

[206.2s - 211.0s]: aware of the Mondragon cooperatives. And I think we've got a real opportunity here to help educate

[211.0s - 217.3s]: folks generally, and especially with our bi-unnerth community audience. And so to kick things off,

[217.3s - 223.3s]: let me just jump right in and ask you, what are the Mondragon cooperatives? Tell us a paint

[223.3s - 228.6s]: of picture for us, what we're talking about. Well, this is an extraordinary complex of

[228.6s - 235.3s]: worker-owned businesses in the Basque region of Spain. They were founded in 1956 with one small

[235.3s - 242.7s]: worker-owned business with five people, five worker owners, who had graduated from this polytechnic

[242.7s - 251.0s]: school that had been founded by a Catholic priest in Mondragon. His name was Father Jose Maria

[251.0s - 257.7s]: Rismendi Adieta. He had the vision and really an extraordinary vision, but he was also a very

[257.7s - 264.4s]: practical man. And he realized coming to the Basque region with a very high unemployment rate in the

[264.4s - 270.7s]: late 40s, early 50s, that what they needed was to educate the people there so they could qualify

[270.7s - 276.6s]: for the industrial jobs that were available. And that's why he started the school. And out of that

[276.6s - 284.4s]: school, five of these students created Fogor, which is, it was called Old Gor, then, but it's

[284.4s - 292.8s]: changed his name to Fogor. And the industrial appliance Fogor still exists today. And that was the

[292.8s - 299.3s]: beginning with five people. Today, it's almost 100 work, or maybe it's a little over 100 worker

[299.3s - 307.6s]: on businesses and probably between 85 and 90,000 worker owners. It fluctuates, but that's approximately

[307.6s - 314.5s]: what it is. So it became huge in this amount of time. And also what it fostered in the region is

[314.5s - 321.9s]: in the 40s and 50s, 1940s and 50s. The Basque region was the poorest area of Spain. Today,

[321.9s - 328.7s]: it's the wealthiest area of Spain. So that has really come about through the plethora of worker

[328.7s - 335.1s]: on cooperatives. Mondragon is the biggest consortium of cooperatives, but they're also probably an

[335.1s - 340.3s]: additional thousand cooperatives in the Basque region. So it's a huge movement in the entire

[340.3s - 348.6s]: culture. That's kind of extraordinary. That is extraordinary. And you know, I guess I'll give it a

[348.6s - 353.4s]: way. I did a bit of a deep dive studying Mondragon when I was in graduate school looking at

[353.4s - 360.5s]: sustainable economic models of some couple decades ago. And when I've shared with folks what I learned

[360.5s - 366.2s]: about Mondragon, one of the ways I like to orient folks to understand where this is geographically

[366.2s - 373.7s]: and culturally is by mentioning, it's my understanding at least that this pretty well known painting by

[379.8s - 390.0s]: disfigured folks in the painting is his depiction of a bombing that occurred just prior to World War

[390.0s - 397.2s]: 2, as I understand it, when the dictator Franco gave Hitler permission basically to test the

[397.2s - 404.7s]: Air Force, the Luftwaffe, the German Nazi war machine. And of course, these people in this region of

[404.7s - 414.4s]: the Pyrenees tucked right there against the Bay of Biscay have undergone some different injustices

[414.4s - 419.9s]: and brutality through history as a specific ethnic group in that region as I understand it.

[420.0s - 424.4s]: Is that right? Can you tell us a bit about that? Yes, you know, the Franco regime was very

[424.4s - 430.3s]: oppressive for the BASC people generally. And they, I think this is the reason why the

[430.3s - 436.5s]: London and to operatives have always kept somewhat of a low profile. And part of it is they had to

[436.5s - 442.5s]: during the Franco regime. And Erasmundi Arietta, the priest, was actually arrested at one point,

[442.8s - 450.2s]: but because it's a Catholic country and even the right wing people were Catholics, so they

[455.4s - 461.6s]: to keep a low profile. And it also meant during Franco's years that they could not teach their

[507.4s - 511.9s]: It's, well, it's fascinating. You know, I've been there 11 times now and sat through 11 of our

[532.9s - 538.6s]: Some of our roads here are noisy and they're not whatever they paid them with. They seem to be

[562.0s - 568.6s]: living in the streets. There is none of that. And they have pretty much eliminated the low end

[568.6s - 575.8s]: of the economics spectrum. Poverty is pretty much erased in the BASC region. And it's incredible to

[575.8s - 582.1s]: experience a society that has learned the concept of enough so that you also don't have this

[582.9s - 588.9s]: small group of people who own and run everything and make the most money. I would say,

[589.2s - 595.9s]: primarily, the BASC region, to me, looks like gradations of middle class. And there's, you know,

[596.0s - 600.2s]: upper middle class, obviously. And there's probably that there are people who are quite wealthy who

[600.2s - 607.4s]: live there, especially around Sands of Ashton. But you don't see displays of great wealth. You don't

[607.4s - 617.4s]: see gated communities. And people live well. Everybody lives well. That's part of the joy of going

[617.4s - 624.5s]: there is that you feel like you're in a very caring society in that region. How delightful and what

[624.5s - 632.9s]: an example for so many of the rest of us in the world. And with the mongergone cooperatives in

[632.9s - 640.5s]: particular, this is not just an accident of culture. This is a very intentional approach to

[641.0s - 648.3s]: community and business and how we conduct ourselves economically in our ecosystems of human

[648.3s - 655.8s]: relations and otherwise. And I was struck to learn about the 10 principles of the mongergone

[655.8s - 661.3s]: cooperatives. And I was hoping we could run through those for our audience and chat a bit about

[661.3s - 666.5s]: them. And I'm happy to rattle them off real quick since I have a list here, Georgia, unless you'd

[672.9s - 679.7s]: all the different ones. And as you see from you're looking at it too, is the center of this logo here

[679.7s - 686.9s]: is education. So from education springs all the rest. And there has to be an understanding of what

[686.9s - 694.1s]: cooperatives are about, of why they're important. So that's kind of the beginning. And it's certainly

[694.1s - 699.5s]: where father, he resmedia, reeta began. It was with the polytechnic school, with an education,

[699.5s - 706.7s]: with discussions. And that helps form the base of what would eventually be the cooperatives.

[707.6s - 711.8s]: And I don't know that we need to go through all of them, but I'm going to mention once that I

[711.8s - 717.2s]: think are really particularly important for people to know about. You see wage solidarity on that

[717.2s - 727.6s]: wheel. And that means that the lowest income of a worker owner is only the CEO of that company is

[727.6s - 733.7s]: probably only making six times what he is making our she. So there's this ratio one to six

[735.0s - 741.1s]: for salaries, which is extraordinary. It means you don't have CEOs making 300 times what the

[741.1s - 748.6s]: lowest paid worker is making. This is wage solidarity. So this is also why you don't have this great big

[749.9s - 756.4s]: or not big, but big in terms of earning. You don't have people with lots of money. And then another

[756.4s - 761.8s]: group that's just barely making it working for the same company. This never happens in a modern

[761.8s - 771.3s]: and company. And that's wage solidarity. And to cooperation is another really important one.

[772.8s - 777.1s]: But I'm going to talk about open admission too, because I think this is interesting. And it's a

[777.8s - 784.4s]: quality that Americans sometimes misread. And I think the reason to think anyone could become a member

[784.4s - 791.7s]: of monitor. Well, the way it works is if you apply for a job or have an idea for a job,

[792.5s - 801.9s]: you can apply, but there's also an 18 month, I guess, reassessment period. Do you fit from your

[801.9s - 807.0s]: point of view? Do you fit from their point of view? So before you actually can become a worker owner,

[807.3s - 813.8s]: there is this time of reflection and seeing if it's a good fit. So open admission means yes,

[813.8s - 819.9s]: they're open for other people beside masked people to apply for jobs. But it also means there are

[819.9s - 826.8s]: boundaries, there are standards that have to be met. So it's not a free for all. And I think the

[826.8s - 834.5s]: other way I would look at that is because it's one worker, one share, one vote. No one can

[834.5s - 842.0s]: amass shares in a company. It's one worker owner, one share. And if they leave, they can cash out

[842.0s - 849.7s]: their share, but they can't sell it. So that means that they are not available to be taken over by

[849.7s - 857.5s]: another corporation or a large business in Spain or even internationally. So that has protected

[857.5s - 865.1s]: the cooperatives. It's one of the smartest things I think at the beginning that the vision was to

[865.1s - 873.1s]: see that in order to maintain that integrity of the cooperatives, they need to not be available

[873.1s - 879.4s]: for takeover. So it's important, I think, to understand what open admission means to them. It's

[879.4s - 885.3s]: a little bit different than sometimes Americans take it to me, which is one of the reasons why I

[885.3s - 891.5s]: felt it was important to talk about it. The one that fascinates me, and from the first time I saw

[891.5s - 899.2s]: this wheel, I was so motivated by it, is the one on the outer part of the wheel, social transformation.

[900.4s - 906.0s]: And they are focused on transforming the culture. Cooperatives do transform a culture.

[907.2s - 921.4s]: And last year, and this year when we have our seminar in September, we will go again to a center in

[921.4s - 927.8s]: how to manifest social transformation in a community. So they work in different areas of Spain,

[929.1s - 937.1s]: in third world countries. They work in a lot of different countries in this idea of how you transform

[937.1s - 943.2s]: a culture. I won't go into it all now, but we do go into it with the NGO that does this work when we're

[943.2s - 951.2s]: in Spain. And it's fascinating to me because my question has always been, society is going to change.

[951.4s - 958.2s]: It has to change culturally. There has to be an understanding at a very deep level of

[959.3s - 964.9s]: how things really change permanently, not just a revolution where it kind of goes around and

[964.9s - 971.1s]: comes around, but something that evolves outside of the norm that people have gotten used to.

[971.7s - 977.4s]: So social transformation to me has been one of the key things of understanding how

[978.4s - 983.1s]: these cooperatives function and what their role in the society has become.

[984.4s - 988.8s]: So exciting. I wanted to connect a couple of dots for our audience.

[989.4s - 997.4s]: Georgia, first of all, with respect to the wage solidarity, which I sometimes will refer to as

[1020.7s - 1027.2s]: established such a beautiful example here. And I know of some other companies and organizations

[1046.3s - 1052.8s]: wage differential cap, which is I think 1 to 5. It might be 1 to 6, but I recall 1 to 5 off the

[1097.7s - 1103.5s]: to 16th. So we meet on a Sunday at the airport in Bilbao and we have our transfer bus that takes

[1110.4s - 1116.5s]: in the hills just above Mondragon. It's many, many acres of land. It's a beautiful place. It's a

[1116.5s - 1124.3s]: renovated 14th century villa. It's been renovated for classes, basically. And it's just gorgeous. And

[1124.3s - 1129.7s]: they also have a dining hall where we have our lunches every day. And then we go on excursions. We

[1244.0s - 1251.4s]: And so we eat at their cafeteria, which is like a gourmet restaurant. It's not like a normal

[1251.4s - 1257.5s]: cafeteria. Excellent food in the region. As probably many people know, they have lots of

[1257.5s - 1264.2s]: multi-star visual and restaurants in the Basque region. They're noted for this. So there's

[1271.9s - 1280.7s]: That's food is one of their things. They're noted for. I love that. And I've been a

[1288.1s - 1293.9s]: So on is one of my favorite sports. And I'm struck just to pick up on this food thread for a brief

[1425.6s - 1432.7s]: One thing that they do have is a large supermarket chain called arosky. And they are all over Spain.

segments.text: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,
we're visiting with Georgia Kelly, the Executive Director of the Praxis Peace Institute. Hi,
and I am so excited for this conversation in particular. It feels as if I've been anticipating this
for 20, 25 years, which might become clear in the course of our conversation why. But essentially,
the reason is, you're an expert on the Mondragon Cooperative System and amazing community and corporate
structure over in the Basque region of Spain, which is going to form much of the topic of our
conversation today. Right. So excited. I hate hesitate to use the word expert. I feel like I
know a fair amount because I've been there many times and spent a lot of time there, but I hesitate
to use that word. No problem whatsoever. I'll use it for you.
Georgia Kelly is the founder and executive director of Praxis Peace Institute. She has produced and
directed several multi-day conferences in Europe and the United States and continues to create
educational programs for Praxis. In addition to leading seminars and tours abroad in places like
Italy, Cuba, Croatia, and Spain, she developed a week-long seminar and tour at the Mondragon
Cooperatives in Spain, which has become a signature program at Praxis. As a dedicated advocate for
cooperatives, she compiled the Mondragon report and account of how the Praxis and Mondragon seminar
has impacted the cooperative movement in the United States. Georgia is also an active citizen and
has chaired several issue-based political organizations and educational forums. She served as a
delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1992. That's Governor Jerry Brown in California.
Georgia also holds a certificate in conflict resolution from Sonoma State University
and teaches conflict resolution workshops and mediation. In 2013, she edited and co-authored
uncivil liberties, deconstructing libertarianism, a critique of libertarian ideas and laissez-faire
capitalism written from the perspective of three academics and three activists. Her previous career was
as a musician, harpist, composer, and recording artist. And Georgia, it's such a pleasure to have you
on the show. And I believe that what we're going to be talking about today, particularly the
Mondragon cooperatives, provides such a tremendously important framework for many of us engaged in this
regenerative stewardship sustainability movement. And I find in many of my conversations, especially
here in the United States, that a handful of folks here and there are aware of the Mondragon
cooperatives, but a whole lot of folks are already engaged in really important work, aren't yet
aware of the Mondragon cooperatives. And I think we've got a real opportunity here to help educate
folks generally, and especially with our bi-unnerth community audience. And so to kick things off,
let me just jump right in and ask you, what are the Mondragon cooperatives? Tell us a paint
of picture for us, what we're talking about. Well, this is an extraordinary complex of
worker-owned businesses in the Basque region of Spain. They were founded in 1956 with one small
worker-owned business with five people, five worker owners, who had graduated from this polytechnic
school that had been founded by a Catholic priest in Mondragon. His name was Father Jose Maria
Rismendi Adieta. He had the vision and really an extraordinary vision, but he was also a very
practical man. And he realized coming to the Basque region with a very high unemployment rate in the
late 40s, early 50s, that what they needed was to educate the people there so they could qualify
for the industrial jobs that were available. And that's why he started the school. And out of that
school, five of these students created Fogor, which is, it was called Old Gor, then, but it's
changed his name to Fogor. And the industrial appliance Fogor still exists today. And that was the
beginning with five people. Today, it's almost 100 work, or maybe it's a little over 100 worker
on businesses and probably between 85 and 90,000 worker owners. It fluctuates, but that's approximately
what it is. So it became huge in this amount of time. And also what it fostered in the region is
in the 40s and 50s, 1940s and 50s. The Basque region was the poorest area of Spain. Today,
it's the wealthiest area of Spain. So that has really come about through the plethora of worker
on cooperatives. Mondragon is the biggest consortium of cooperatives, but they're also probably an
additional thousand cooperatives in the Basque region. So it's a huge movement in the entire
culture. That's kind of extraordinary. That is extraordinary. And you know, I guess I'll give it a
way. I did a bit of a deep dive studying Mondragon when I was in graduate school looking at
sustainable economic models of some couple decades ago. And when I've shared with folks what I learned
about Mondragon, one of the ways I like to orient folks to understand where this is geographically
and culturally is by mentioning, it's my understanding at least that this pretty well known painting by
Picasso called Guernica, which is sort of monochromatic kind of black, white, and gray with all these
disfigured folks in the painting is his depiction of a bombing that occurred just prior to World War
2, as I understand it, when the dictator Franco gave Hitler permission basically to test the
Air Force, the Luftwaffe, the German Nazi war machine. And of course, these people in this region of
the Pyrenees tucked right there against the Bay of Biscay have undergone some different injustices
and brutality through history as a specific ethnic group in that region as I understand it.
Is that right? Can you tell us a bit about that? Yes, you know, the Franco regime was very
oppressive for the BASC people generally. And they, I think this is the reason why the
London and to operatives have always kept somewhat of a low profile. And part of it is they had to
during the Franco regime. And Erasmundi Arietta, the priest, was actually arrested at one point,
but because it's a Catholic country and even the right wing people were Catholics, so they
couldn't really hold a priest indefinitely, which they didn't. But it was a lesson, you know,
to keep a low profile. And it also meant during Franco's years that they could not teach their
own BASC language nor use it in the schools. So there was quite an oppressive
but I would say on the neck of the BASC people during that time. And
fortunately when he passed on things changed and now a whole generation has learned the BASC
language. Most people there speak it, but there is one generation that didn't learn it. And it was
the one coming of age during Franco's regime. So they all speak Spanish, a lot of them speak English
and most of them speak BASC at this point. Tell us a bit about the region in terms of, you know,
how it looks, what's the food like, what's the topography, what's the landscape and culture like?
It's, well, it's fascinating. You know, I've been there 11 times now and sat through 11 of our
seminars that we have at Inmondragon. And what I've learned, you know, from the first time I went
to even now, the same thing happens. Get off the airplane and you're taking a ride into Mondragon
from Bilbao. The roads are just perfectly maintained. There are no potholes. They're not noisy.
Some of our roads here are noisy and they're not whatever they paid them with. They seem to be
well maintained. They're quiet. And the whole region looks, it is, very well maintained, cared for,
appreciated. You don't see messes anywhere. And one of the things that everybody notes when they
go on our seminar is, you don't see poverty. You don't see slums. You don't see people
living in the streets. There is none of that. And they have pretty much eliminated the low end
of the economics spectrum. Poverty is pretty much erased in the BASC region. And it's incredible to
experience a society that has learned the concept of enough so that you also don't have this
small group of people who own and run everything and make the most money. I would say,
primarily, the BASC region, to me, looks like gradations of middle class. And there's, you know,
upper middle class, obviously. And there's probably that there are people who are quite wealthy who
live there, especially around Sands of Ashton. But you don't see displays of great wealth. You don't
see gated communities. And people live well. Everybody lives well. That's part of the joy of going
there is that you feel like you're in a very caring society in that region. How delightful and what
an example for so many of the rest of us in the world. And with the mongergone cooperatives in
particular, this is not just an accident of culture. This is a very intentional approach to
community and business and how we conduct ourselves economically in our ecosystems of human
relations and otherwise. And I was struck to learn about the 10 principles of the mongergone
cooperatives. And I was hoping we could run through those for our audience and chat a bit about
them. And I'm happy to rattle them off real quick since I have a list here, Georgia, unless you'd
like to, if you've got it off the top of your head. I do. I have the logo right in front of me with
all the different ones. And as you see from you're looking at it too, is the center of this logo here
is education. So from education springs all the rest. And there has to be an understanding of what
cooperatives are about, of why they're important. So that's kind of the beginning. And it's certainly
where father, he resmedia, reeta began. It was with the polytechnic school, with an education,
with discussions. And that helps form the base of what would eventually be the cooperatives.
And I don't know that we need to go through all of them, but I'm going to mention once that I
think are really particularly important for people to know about. You see wage solidarity on that
wheel. And that means that the lowest income of a worker owner is only the CEO of that company is
probably only making six times what he is making our she. So there's this ratio one to six
for salaries, which is extraordinary. It means you don't have CEOs making 300 times what the
lowest paid worker is making. This is wage solidarity. So this is also why you don't have this great big
or not big, but big in terms of earning. You don't have people with lots of money. And then another
group that's just barely making it working for the same company. This never happens in a modern
and company. And that's wage solidarity. And to cooperation is another really important one.
But I'm going to talk about open admission too, because I think this is interesting. And it's a
quality that Americans sometimes misread. And I think the reason to think anyone could become a member
of monitor. Well, the way it works is if you apply for a job or have an idea for a job,
you can apply, but there's also an 18 month, I guess, reassessment period. Do you fit from your
point of view? Do you fit from their point of view? So before you actually can become a worker owner,
there is this time of reflection and seeing if it's a good fit. So open admission means yes,
they're open for other people beside masked people to apply for jobs. But it also means there are
boundaries, there are standards that have to be met. So it's not a free for all. And I think the
other way I would look at that is because it's one worker, one share, one vote. No one can

the cooperatives. It's one of the smartest things I think at the beginning that the vision was to
see that in order to maintain that integrity of the cooperatives, they need to not be available

a little bit different than sometimes Americans take it to me, which is one of the reasons why I
felt it was important to talk about it. The one that fascinates me, and from the first time I saw
